subject: RE: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: ... Why do you say that?  I think this is pure speculation, but if you have some actual metrics I would be interested in seeing them. ... Again, I am baffled
messageBody:
> Lurker here, but I thought I'd chime in to agree with
> Vladimir on this. In an ideal world, test cases might
> stay separate, but the first hurdle is often just
> getting developers to write them, and that's a lot
> easier to manage when the test case lives in the same
> package as their code.

Why do you say that? I think this is pure speculation, but if you have some
actual metrics I would be interested in seeing them.

> Co-mingling increases the chances that they'll use the
> test case for all of their incremental testing
> (instead of writing little mini-clients or main()
> methods to test/debug), and helps make unit testing
> seem like part of the development process instead of a
> post-coding chore.

Again, I am baffled at your logic, but if you have actual results please
share them.

> We can always auto-repackage stuff later,

This is a burden on the process. If tests are going to be split out anyway,
and there is no good design reason why they should be with production code,
then initially put them where they are intended to be. Also, depending on
your source control system, this could be somewhat detrimental to your
company's history markers and metrics. Moving a class out of one package to
another (which we must do from time to time) will cause another root to be
formed in the new package and an orphaned leaf in the old. You could lose
valuable history. Not to mention that in distributed team environments
others may be expecting for your class(es) to be "in the same ol' place" and
if you move them, you cause some degree of hassle. Sometimes this is
unavoidable, but I think it is a bad practice to get into.

> but in my
> experience, it's not always easy to get people to go
> back and write test cases when there's more
> interesting work to be done.

That is a fault of not doing test-first which you will face no matter where
the test cases live. The thought in my mind is that tests are an integral
part of the system, they drive the design for us (in XP). They are not some
special case group of bastardized objects that can be taken or not. They
are essential. Don Wells once said (I believe it was Don, if anyone knows
differently please correct me), "Throw away my code, but never throw away my
tests." Point being that he would be able to rebuild the system again from
scratch if he had the tests. If you threw away the tests and gave him the
production code, he would be floundering in agony to reproduce all of those
tests.

Tests are not simply obilgatory objects that satisfy some requirements from
management... they are the life-sustaining power of the code, in my opinion!

-Jason
